topic.title: HPE Helion Development Platform 2.0: Managed Service Connectivity to ALS Clusters and Applications
topic.abstract: Procedure to connect managed services to an ALS cluster or applications.This document describes the steps required to connect managed HDP application services instances/clusters to an HDP ALS cluster and to connect to applications in that ALS cluster.

section.p:
The following application services come built-in with HPE Helion Development Platform:
Database Service (Trove): MySQL, Redis, MongoDB, Vertica Preview (single instances and clusters)
Message Broker: RabbitMQ clusters
Typically, application services can be bound to an ALS cluster via the standard Cloud Foundry User Provided Service mechanism. MySQL instances and clusters are bound to ALS clusters via the Service Gateway mechanism.

ul.li: You have access to Helion OpenStack deployer node or a jump box that is on the same network as Trove control plane such as the Trove management network.

You can run Trove client commands such as trove list. You can install the Trove client by running sudo apt-get install python-troveclient on the machine you will run Trove commands. More information on how to obtain and use the Trove CLI can be found here.

You have access to an HDP ALS cluster, and can run the helion client to manage the cluster and push applications. For more information on ALS clusters and their usage, see the ALS User's Guide or the full helion client reference.

Connectivity from ALS cluster to user-provided services: It is required that ALS cluster(s) and user-provided service instance(s) and cluster(s) be on the same network. On the ALS cluster that you will deploy applications, to be able to access user-provided service instances, you need to configure to allow network traffic to IPâ€™s and ports for these service instances/clusters. For each service instance or cluster you create, you also need to configure ALS cluster to allow access to it. Here it is assumed that you have already configured your ALS cluster for access to each service instance or cluster.
